Show HN: An open-source alternative to Tableau based on the Grammar of Graphics
text:
Graphic Walker is an open-source alternative to Tableau. It allows data scientists to analyze data and visualize patterns with simple drag-and-drop operations.

Main features: A drag and drop based interaction for exploratory data analysis with visualizations.

A grammar of graphics based visual analytic user interface where users can build visualization from low-level visual channel encodings.

A Data Explainer(tableau explain data) which explains why some patterns occur / what may cause them.

Easy to embed in your app as a simple react component !

Welcome to discuss ideas and advice with me in github or discord.

Ask HN: Tool for tracking third-party services?
text:
I would be grateful if someone knows of a tool - possibly a SaaS - that allows a small team to keep track of all the third-party services they are using and paying for. Ideally, it would support management of the details such as:

* The membership tier/subscription type

* Cost of the service (monthly, annual, per user etc)

* Dates of any renewals (ideally with reminders)

* Team members with admin/privileged access

etc

Any suggestions welcome!

Tell HN: I hate the existing classification of hypervisors
text:
Maybe the reason for this is that I'm undereducated, but still.

If you google comparison of hypervisors you will inevitably see "type 1" and "type 2" hypervisors being mentioned. Which is a distinction made in 70s. The idea behind is that with "type 1" the hypervisor is launched on bare metal and with "type 2" first a normal, common OS is launched, and hypervisor is launched inside it.

This is a completely pointless distinction nowadays I think.

If you want a VM with a best performance, it doesn't matter what hypervisor will you use — xen, kvm, esxi. Ultimately, your VM will use hardware virtualization extensions which any modern CPU provides.

The distinction that xen is "type 1" and kvm is "type 2" because they boot differently is completely pointless, who cares how the hypervisor boots if the end result is the same?

Note: I know you don't have to enable cpu hardware virtualization with xen, so the end result can be different. But the point stands: the classification is pointless, why care how the system boots, you should care how it runs VMs.

The future of internet? Wormholes and strongly typed URLs
text:
Worms are URL which are allowed to pop from the page into any other process beyond the browser.

Method:

- Continually printscreen

- OCR or image detection

- Process wormholes according to standardized types/archetypes

- Only allow specific worms/URL types from those to run automatically (for security)

Example: allow imgur worms to auto-display imgur pictures as a display notification, or ideally (as a compatible browser's plugin) insert into the page where the worm text is situated, beyond what the webpage initially allows. This gives power to the user.

I always get downvoted for having controversial ideas but this time I have the agreement of ChatGPT/OpenAI so I feel vindicated already.

Here's what it says about the idea of internet wormholes:

https://imgur.com/UZnU5c8

Ask HN: I'm 40 and feel my mental ability declining. Programming seems harder
text:
I'm around 40 and recently I have been asked to port an API from one language to another. The code I'm porting is average code, not terrible, but plenty of little things to complain about.

I feel like my past self could have handled this task, but I am really struggling. Porting this API will require a deep understanding of the existing API, which, of course, has several layers of abstraction.

I can't seem to hold more than about 2 levels of call stack in my head. There's the entry point function which calls other functions, which call other functions, which call other functions, etc. You know how it is, code calls other code, and logically it forms a tree of calls and return values that often goes several layers deep. I struggle to hold more than about 2 levels of this call stack in my head. By the time I'm down in the weeds I've forgotten what I'm doing, what the purpose of the actual API call is.

I don't know how to break this into small enough chunks that I can understand it or make progress. Imagine I gave you the code for the sha512 algorithm, and a hash, and asked you to find the pre-image (the input). This is how I feel. Where do I even get started? How do I find even a single chunk of manageable work to break off.

The hard part is, several other developers are making progress on porting this API. Why can't I? What happened?

I don't know if this task is just an especially bad fit for me, or if my mental abilities are declining?
